webServer

Class MicroWebServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • webServer.MicroWebServer

  • public class MicroWebServer
extends java.lang.Object
    MicroWebServer is a tiny implementation that sets up a webserver that returns a constant HTTP Response 200 status code. It is a basic program that uses the ServerSocket class. The aim of this class is to:
    • Illustrate a simple server implementation on Java
    • How a server socket listens on the server side
    • Process the client's request and return a simple HTML page

    Author:
    tabcina
    See Also:
    ServerSocket

      • initialize

        public void initialize(java.lang.Integer SERVER_PORT_NUMBER)
                throws java.io.IOException,
                       java.lang.Exception
        Starts the MicroWebServer
        Parameters:
        SERVER_PORT_NUMBER - port on which the server listens to incoming requests (80 as per convention)
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an input/output error occurs when opening the socket.
        java.lang.Exception - thrown in case of any other abnormal behavior

      • processRequest

        public void processRequest(java.net.ServerSocket serverSocket)
        Processes the incoming client requests
        Parameters:
        serverSocket - that accepts incoming client requests
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an input/output error occurs when opening the socket.
        java.lang.Exception - thrown in case of any unexpected behavior
        See Also:
        ServerSocket

      • readHeadersFromRequest

        public void readHeadersFromRequest(java.lang.String request)
        Validates request with GET and HTTP/1.1 headers
        Parameters:
        request - sent my client (socket)

      • returnOKResponse

        public void returnOKResponse(java.io.PrintWriter out)
        Sends back the response headers:
        • A hard-coded 200 status code, and
        • The content-type of the resource (html)
        Parameters:
        out - object to send the text-output stream back to the client.

      • main
